data.title: adb restart
data.body:
- Create an app
- Use one-click deploy (launch on android)
- App should work fine on android
- run adb kill-server
- adb start-server
- Click on one-click deploy 
- Now you see play icon without any text
- Click on it... ooops

Device appeared as `????????????    no permissions` . Of course Godot should react somehow different

data.title: Use cStringIO to write editor_icons.cpp
data.body: - Multiple jobs might try to access editor_icons.cpp when sCons is updating it. cStringIO helps to  minimize the blocking window, hence lower the chance getting file access conflict error when building with multiple jobs

data.title: added XClassHint to windows in OS_X11::initialize
data.body:
added XClassHint to windows in OS_X11::initialize for improved window management in x11.

This actually makes godot show up in Cairo Dock where it wasn't properly before.

data.title: Add get_scale script binding to Matrix32 class

data.body: Added a setting to disable autocomplete popup (only use ctrl+space) and fixed the autocomplete timer to updated when the setting has changed (changing the delay did not update before relaunch)

data.title: [Suggestion] Make the debug output text selectable (and copyable) from within the Godot editor
[GNU/Linux] Key states get stuck (very significant issue!)
data.body:
See [this forum thread](http://www.godotengine.org/forum/viewtopic.php?f=11&t=503&start=10#p2546) for some additional information and observations that other people have made about this problem. I recommend closely reading from the post I linked above and onwards (rather than backwards), because the forward posts try to focus in on and pinpoint the problem with Godot a bit more than previous posts.

I can't speak for everyone, but it seems like many GNU/Linux users are hitting up against this issue, and it's reproducible in _every_ demo that accepts input (i.e. Platformer, Platformer 3D, Kinematic Collision, Pong, etc.).

In short, the engine's Input key states sometimes fail to update (this can be observed by comparing the output of `Input.is_key_pressed(key)` to the actual state of your keyboard, for instance). **The input event dispatcher itself does not fail; all InputEvents for pressing and releasing keys seem to be properly dispatched even when key states stick, so if the user wants to reinvent the wheel by recreating her own input mapper instead of using Godot's, she can.**

The failure to update is not random, but predictable; the following pattern appears to be consistent:
- If you release one key and press another at the same time, neither key will change states within Input (even though the InputEvents are properly dispatched). I've noticed that some key combinations are far more difficult to reproduce this with than others.
## A simple demonstration

Here's a little keyboard I wrote using GDScript to visualize the engine's key states for better testing this issue:
![keyboard demonstration](http://i.imgur.com/RadFIko.png)

Here's the code:

``` python
extends Node2D

const KEY_SIZE = 58
const KEY_PADDING = 5

var keyboard = [
    {"offset": 0, "keys": "`1234567890-="},
    {"offset": KEY_SIZE*1.5, "keys": "QWERTYUIOP[]"},
    {"offset": KEY_SIZE*1.75, "keys": "ASDFGHJKL;'"},
    {"offset": KEY_SIZE*2.25, "keys": "ZXCVBNM,./"}
]

class Key:
    extends Node2D

    const IDLE_COLOR = Color(0.5, 0.5, 0.5)
    const PRESSED_COLOR = Color(0.8, 0.6, 0.5)

    var key
    var label

    func _init(key, x, y, width, height):
        set_pos(Vector2(x, y))
        self.key = key

        label = Label.new()
        label.set_text(key)
        var label_offset = KEY_SIZE/2 - label.get_line_height()/2
        label.set_pos(Vector2(label_offset, label_offset))
        add_child(label)

        set_process_input(true)

    func _draw():
        var color
        if Input.is_key_pressed(key.ord_at(0)):
            color = PRESSED_COLOR
        else:
            color = IDLE_COLOR

        var offset = KEY_PADDING
        var size = KEY_SIZE - offset*2
        draw_rect(Rect2(offset, offset, size, size), color)

    func _input(e):
        update()

func _input(e):
    print(OS.get_unix_time(), " ", e)

func _ready():
    set_process_input(true)
    for row in range(keyboard.size()):
        var r = keyboard[row]
        for key in range(r.keys.length()):
            generate_key(r.keys[key], key, row)

func generate_key(key, x, y):
    var key_x = keyboard[y].offset + x*KEY_SIZE
    var key_y = y*KEY_SIZE
    add_child(Key.new(key, key_x, key_y, KEY_SIZE, KEY_SIZE))
```

Say I'm pressing the **L** key:
![keyboard demonstration](http://i.imgur.com/vZ9HAcX.png)

If I press the **K** key and release the **L** key at the same time, the key states still think I'm just holding down **L**, even though I'm actually holding down **K** on my keyboard:
![keyboard demonstration](http://i.imgur.com/vZ9HAcX.png)

This is a log of the InputEvents that were dispatched (along with unix timestamps as I shifted from the **L** key to the **K** key:
![log from keyboard demonstration](http://i.imgur.com/DwPzZ5j.png)
As you can see, the Input events dispatched properly even though the Input key states failed to update!

data.title: drawing on background
data.body:
Create a scene (Control in the root) with a button in it

```
extends Control
func _draw():
    var r = Rect2(Vector2(),get_size()/3)
    draw_rect(r, Color(0,0,0))
func _ready():
    pass
```
- Run it on PC - works fine, right?
- Run on an Android device - oh, this is a pixel horror!

This is a example proj: https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/34699053/drawTest.zip

data.title: Add 2d unifrom scale
data.body:
User usually expect "shift" key to be the modify key for unifrom scale:

![](http://i57.tinypic.com/2cwpok1.jpg)
A sprite to sclae

![](http://i61.tinypic.com/1zn6i3c.jpg)
Hold "Shift" and dragging corner to scale it uniformly

Godot's old "shift" symmetric scale behavior is keeped by using "Alt" key:

![](http://i58.tinypic.com/2is8mjo.jpg)
Hold "Shift" + "Alt" and dragging corner to scale it uniformly from center

data.title: parser and debugger shows the wrong line error
data.body:
how to reproduce:

```
var test = [ "1" ]
func _ready():
    # Initalization here
    if (1>0):
        pass
    elif(1<0):
        pass
    elif(1<0):
        pass
    elif(1<0):
        pass
    elif(1<0):
        pass
    print (test + 1)
```

```
invalid operands 'array' and 'int' in operator +
```

error stops in the first elif instead of the print. Its confusing

```
    draw_circle(get_size() / 2, 10, Color(1,0,0))

func _ready():

```

data.title: Fixed issue #429: in scene tab, clicking on some instance folder, change all the others views
data.body:
- Fix issue #429
- Script editor plugin try to restore state after sub-scene loaded, if there were scripts opened, will trigger loading resource and will make script tab visible. Solved it by select scene node after restoring plugins' state

data.title: in scene tab, clicking on some instance folder, change all the others views
data.body: in the scene tab when you click on the folder of some instance to go to the scene, it changes views from current (2d) to script and to the resources tab (from scene tab)... not sure if this info used to be saved with the scene or what... but not anymore...

data.title: in help tab node tree moving away when clicking
data.body: in the help tab, when you click on some node on the node tree... the node tree moves down! you dont even get to see the selected node

data.title: Script editor - mouse wheel problem
data.body:
I'am set breakpoint in code. When breakpoint is execute game stop, and script editor jump to line code when breakpoint is set. After press F8 windows script editor like this:

![beztytuu](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5302754/3007497/e4283db2-de8a-11e3-9d3a-a36046bc5e64.png)
As it can be seen on screenshot vertical scrollbar is not showing. Scroll to line 1 is possible only by arrow key, mouse wheel not working.
